thread.title: Cubs slug 6 HRs, take 2-1 NLDS lead over Cardinals
thread.title_full: Cubs slug 6 HRs, take 2-1 NLDS lead over Cardinals

title: Cubs slug 6 HRs, take 2-1 NLDS lead over Cardinals
text:
Anthony Rizzo celebrates with Kyle Schwarber after a solo home run in the fifth inning. (Photo: Jerry Lai, USA TODAY Sports)
110 CONNECT 61 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE CHICAGO -- Maybe they’re too naive to actually understand what they’re doing.
Maybe they’re just too young to realize they’re supposed to be nervous wrecks.
Maybe, just maybe, the Chicago Cubs’ kiddie corps is so darned talented, it really doesn’t make a difference.
The Cubs, 8-6 winners over the St. Louis Cardinals, slugged a playoff record six homers by six players, and moved within one victory Monday of their first postseason series clinching party at Wrigley Field since, well, ever.
The Cubs have never clinched a playoff series at home in franchise history.
Why, even when they last won the World Series in 1908, and playing their home games at West Side Grounds, they won the deciding game in Detroit.
The Cubs lead the best-of-five series, 2-1, and a victory Tuesday (4:07 ET) would invoke the biggest party in the North Side of town since 2003, when they won the Division Series against the Atlanta Braves, but on the road.
“It would be nice to win at home here,’’ Cubs rookie Kris Bryant said, “for the fans. The crowd was unbelievable with all of the towels and flags waving. We love playing here.
“Hopefully, we’ll be playing a lot more games here, too.’’
The Cubs, with four kids in their starting lineup barely old enough to drink, relied on their star-studded rookie corps to provide ace Jake Arrieta all the support he needed, on a night when he looked nothing like Jake Arrieta.
Arrieta had given up only four earned runs since the end of July, spanning 95 innings and 1,393 pitches, and he surrendered four runs in just 5 2/3 innings and 97 pitches this night.
It was his shortest outing since June 16 against the Cleveland Indians, stunning the crowd of 42,411, who hadn’t seen Arrieta vulnerable since the outfield ivy was still brown.
“He’s not going to be an oil painting every night,’’ Cubs manager Joe Maddon said. “You can’t be perfect every night, man. It had to come to an end at some point.’’
Hey, no problem.
FOR THE WIN
Cubs hit record six home runs in NLDS Game 3 win
The Cubs delivered the greatest home run onslaught in postseason history. The last time the Cardinals saw an October home run barrage anything close to this was in Game 4 of the 1928 World Series, when Babe Ruth hit three of the New York Yankees’ five homers against them.
“Pretty impressive,’’ Maddon said. “I knew we were definitely capable of doing that.’’
And wouldn’t you know it, the assault was led by the rookie quartet of Jorge Soler, Addison Russell, Kyle Schwarber and Bryant. They came to the old man’s rescue, going six-for-12 with three homers, a triple and five RBI.
It was the first time in Cubs’ history -- spanning 20,738 games -- that their No. 1 to No. 6 hitters homered in the same game, according to ESPN and Elias.
Soler, Schwarber and Bryant also became the youngest set of three teammates, according to ESPN, to hit a home run in the same postseason.
It was that fifth inning that could be remembered for an awfully long time.
It began with a one-out single by Soler, and then who else but Bryant, who had the rafters shaking. He slammed a 94-mph fastball from Cardinals starter Michael Wacha into the left-field bleachers, turning a 2-2 tie into a 4-2 lead.
The place was still jumping when 26-year-old Anthony Rizzo followed with a 430-foot blast into the right-field bleachers, his first hit of the postseason.
How rare are back-to-back postseason homers for the Cubs?
USA TODAY
Armour: After so much disappointment, Cubs fans cherish rare success
Jody Davis and Leon Durham last accomplished the feat 31 years ago in the 1984 NLCS against the San Diego Padres, a series in which the Cubs were one victory away from their first World Series since 1945, only to lose three consecutive games in the best-of-five series.
It was Schwarber, who was attending Indiana University a year ago, doing the early damage with a second inning homer. It was Starlin Castro, 25, in the fourth inning with a homer that had him long admiring it at home plate Russell, who turned 21 this summer, who contributed a triple before leaving the game with a tight left hamstring.
And it was Soler, who became the first player in history to reach base safely in his first nine postseason appearances, homering in the sixth.
Certainly, the loss had to leave the Cardinals demoralized. They’re the first team to get to Arrieta since July, and still lose. They had the Cubs just where they wanted, getting into their bullpen after Jason Heyward’s two-run homer in the sixth, and pulling within one run, 5-4.
Yet, those crazy Cubs’ kids never blinked, with Soler jumping on left-handed reliever Kevin Siegrist’s first pitch, launching it into the right-field bleachers.
“It was like a 2-iron,’’ Bryant said. “It was unbelievable. His at-bats are awesome. He’s seeing the ball, really, really good, and he’s not missing his pitch when he gets it.’’
Certainly, the Cardinals have got to feel demoralized. They’re the first team to get to Arrieta since July, and still they lost
The Cubs know better than to celebrate early. They’ve seen these Cardinals all season long. They’ve seen those 11 World Series flags hanging at Busch Stadium.
And they know that even when the Cardinals look like they’re on life support, they’re never dead.
Besides, the Cardinals have got John Lackey on the mound, the same guy shut out the Cubs for 7 1/3 innings in Game 1, and who now is trying to save the Cardinals’ season.
No offense to the city of St. Louis, or to everyone who would love to see a Game 5, but the Cubs really don’t want to see the city again until next April.
You see, they have a party to attend.
Follow Nightengale on Twitter: @Bnightengale
